title: FirstFT: Left push for talks with Putin
text:
A group of liberal Democrats in the US Congress is pressing Joe Biden to pursue direct talks with Russia's leader Vladimir Putin, opening a new front of pressure on the president's Ukraine strategy as his administration tries to maintain domestic support for Kyiv.

“We urge you to pair the military and economic support the United States has provided to Ukraine with a proactive diplomatic push, redoubling efforts to seek a realistic framework for a ceasefire,” the group wrote in a letter to the White House.

It urged the US to “engage in direct talks with Russia” and “explore prospects for a new European security arrangement acceptable to all parties” before demanding the US “seek a rapid end to the conflict and reiterate this goal as America's chief priority”.

The letter was signed by 30 lawmakers including Ilhan Omar, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Rashida Tlaib and Ayanna Pressley — a group of liberal congresswomen known as “the Squad”.

The fresh division between the Democratic progressives and the White House comes just a week after Republican House leader Kevin McCarthy, warned that future assistance to Ukraine could be limited if the party wins the House of Representatives in November's US midterm elections.

Confirming the letter had been received, John Kirby, a spokesperson for the National Security Council, said the White House appreciates “their thoughtful concerns about what's going on in the war in Ukraine”, but added it was up to Ukraine's president Volodymyr Zelenskyy to decide when to engage with Putin.

Do you agree with the progressives? Is it time for the US to begin direct talks with Russia? Email your thoughts to firstft@ft.com or hit reply on this email? You can also vote in our latest poll.

Five more stories in the news

1. US charges Chinese officers with trying to interfere in Huawei probe The Department of Justice has charged two Chinese intelligence officers with seeking to obstruct the criminal prosecution of Huawei. It alleged Guochun He and Zheng Wang, two Chinese citizens who remain at large, paid a US law enforcement officer $61,000 in bitcoin to obtain information on the prosecution and probe.

2. Trump provides cash injection for Republican Senate hopefuls After sitting out most of the 2022 election cycle, Trump's political action committees are spending millions of dollars in the final weeks of the campaign. Since the beginning of October, Maga Inc, a newly created Trump super Pac, has spent $8.5mn on ads in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Georgia, Nevada and Arizona.

  • FT Live: US columnists Edward Luce and Rana Foroohar, DC bureau chief James Politi and veteran commentator Norm Ornstein will be discussing the results of the midterm election at a special event on November 10.

3. Apple raises prices of TV and music streaming subscriptions Apple said yesterday it was raising prices for its TV+, Music and services-bundle subscriptions for the first time since their respective launches. Apple's move will put further pressure on Spotify to follow suit as consumer face skyrocketing prices.

4. Renminbi hits 2007 low after Xi unveils harder line leadership China's currency has hit its weakest level against the dollar since 2007 as concerns over President Xi Jinping's appointment of a harder line leadership team and a struggling economy spread from equities to currency markets. The fresh renminbi weakness takes its losses against the US currency this year to 13 per cent and follows sharp falls for Chinese equities in Asia and the US yesterday.

5. UBS profits slide as turbulent markets spook rich clients The Swiss bank reported a 24 per cent fall in net profit as its rich clients held back from turbulent markets and investment banking revenues shrank. Conversely, HSBC, the UK biggest bank, reported third-quarter profits that exceeded expectations as it overhauled its leadership team and announced the appointment of a new chief financial officer.

The day ahead

Big Tech earnings Google parent Alphabet and Microsoft will kick off Big Tech earnings after the bell. Their results — as well as those of Amazon, Apple and Meta later this week — will be met with investor scrutiny as they are expected to report slowing revenue growth and a slowdown in advertiser spending. Credit card company Visa also reports on a busy results day that includes Coca-Cola, UPS, Raytheon, General Electric, 3M, and General Motors,

Economic indicators: US home prices in 20 big cities are expected to cool further with price rises decelerating to an annualised rate of 14.4 per cent in August from 16.1 per cent in July as mortgage rates increase, pricing out some would-be homebuyers. Separately, economists expect consumer confidence in the US, as measured by a Conference Board index, to tick down to 106.5 for October from a five-month high of 108 in September, as inflation continues to rage at elevated levels.

US midterms: Democrat John Fetterman and Republican Mehmet Oz will face each other on the debate stage as they vie for a key US Senate seat. The winner of this contest to be a senator from Pennsylvania could tip the balance of power in the upper chamber of Congress. Elsewhere, New York governor Kathy Hochul, a Democrat, will meet her Republican challenger Lee Zeldin for their own debate.

‘Davos in the Desert' begins Jamie Dimon, Stephen Schwarzman and David Solomon will be among the US bankers and investors flocking to Saudi Arabia to speak at the Future Investment Initiative, better known as “Davos in the Desert”.

Britain gets a new PM Rishi Sunak will become the UK's youngest prime minister for more than two centuries and the country's first non-white leader after meeting King Charles at Buckingham Palace. Liz Truss will travel to the palace to resign, confirming her status as the shortest-serving British prime minister.

  • Go deeper: Chief features writer Henry Mance profiles the new UK PM following his rapid rise to the top of British politics.

What else we're reading

The US legal move letting corporations off the hook 3M, the conglomerate, is part of a recent trend whereby US corporations make use of the bankruptcy court not because they are insolvent but to manage tort claims. The manoeuvre is known as the Texas two-step and seeks to exploit loopholes in the legal system but judges are beginning to crack down.

‘Clunky' Bidenomics proves a tough sell Under the Democrats' watch, the US economic recovery has generated 10mn jobs and lowered unemployment to 3.5 per cent since January 2021. But months of unrelentingly high inflation have made “Bidenomics” a difficult sell on the campaign trail.

Xi Jinping's China and the rise of the ‘global west' If the US is to keep its international network of allies together, it will have to persuade its partners that the darkest fears about Russia and China are justified, writes Gideon Rachman. Recent scenes from Beijing help to make that case.

  • Plus: How China's business elites are pulling the trigger on exit plans as pessimism builds over the future of the world's second-largest economy under Xi Jinping.

TSMC faces challenges as world demands ever-smaller chips Chipmakers are bumping up against the laws of physics as they strive to make semiconductors faster and more power-efficient. Will the world's largest contract chipmaker stay ahead of the pack as the industry is forced to develop new transistor technology?

Office workers embrace hybrid working Trips to workplaces in the world's seven largest economies are well below the levels before the coronavirus took hold in early 2020, according to a Financial Times analysis of phone-tracking movements published by Google. Economists say the shift has become the new normal.
